question: Watch out! How deep are we?
answer: 8200 feet. Used to be an old copper mine, Professor, sir.

question: Helmsley told me that the neutrino count doubled during the last sun eruptions.
answer: Correct, sir. But that is not what worries me... There was a new solar storm, so strong that the physical reaction got even more severe.

question: How can that be?
answer: We don't know, Professor, sir. The neutrinos suddenly act like... microwaves.

question: I still can't believe that Wilson chose him of all people to run the White House. Shame he's such a pompous ass.
answer: Somebody mention my name? Which one is it?

question: We were talking about what a great speech you gave tonight. Well done, sir.
answer: It's Helmsley, right? I'll remember that.

question: Sir, the President needs to know this.
answer: Helmsley, how long have you been on the job as science advisor?

question: Four months this week.
answer: I would say that's enough time to learn that we have rules here. You'll just have to wait until the quarterly science briefing.

question: If this is about what I said last night, I am truly sorry, sir.
answer: So you didn't like my speech?

question: Can you please have a look at this, sir? It's really important.
answer: Who wrote this?

question: An Indian astrophysicist I graduated with from Harvard and Prof. West, the preeminent geologist in the US.
answer: Who else knows about it?

question: No one, sir.
answer: Let's keep it that way, Helmsley.

question: So this time we'll hit the Japs.
answer: So what?

question: Well Tony, electronics are cheap there and... you could visit your boy Will.
answer: Afternoon ladies...

question: Are you even listening to me?
answer: Yes unfortunately I am Harry.

question: I heard from Audrey you're a grandpa now.
answer: Why don't you keep your nose out of my family. You're cramping my style.

question: He married a Japanese girl - how is that the end of the world? You should at least go see him.
answer: Why? Do you see your boy?

question: Not as much as I'd like. DC is a long way. But at least we talk.
answer: What about?

question: Life, how short it is...
answer: What the hell was that?

question: Laura? They lied to us.
answer: Manfred is that you?

question: I had my suspicions. I should have said something. They are following me.
answer: Who is?

question: They may be listening to us too. Laura the Heritage Foundation is a sham.
answer: What? Then where is it?

question: You have to see this.
answer: It's alright Sally.

question: I just talked to him, Dad. He told me the world Heritage Foundation is a sham. Is that true? You knew too? You sleep with me and you didn't say anything? I can't even look at you. Either of you!
answer: Honey, calm down.

question: This wasn't here before.
answer: Don't you see the signs?

question: It's fine guys. It's gone. The whole darn lake is gone. I swear you guys there was a lake here.
answer: Jackson!

question: Isn't this supposed to be a National Park? There shouldn't be fences. What are you guys doing around here anyway?
answer: We're geologists... I'll handle this officer. Thank you.

question: So, where did the lake go?
answer: That's what we're trying to find out. We think this whole area has become potentially unstable. I would advise you to take your kids and leave, Mr... ... Curtis. Are you by any chance the Jackson Curtis, the author of `Farewell Atlantis'? What a coincidence. I'm reading your book, as we speak... first third, around day 300, when the shuttle loses communication with earth and drifts off into space.

question: You're one of lucky 422 who bought it.
answer: Actually I didn't buy it. My father gave it to me.

question: Oh, I see.
answer: Officer, can you return them to the campgrounds, please. Pleasure to meet you, Mr. Curtis.

question: ... This is Charlie Frost reporting live from Yellowstone National Park, soon to become the world's largest active volcano.
answer: Hi. Mind if I join you?

question: I only got a few minutes.
answer: I just heard part of your broadcast... Mind me asking a question? What exactly is it... that will start in Hollywood? What are you talking about?

question: ... and Albert Einstein endorsed it... The forces of mother nature will be so devastating it will bring an end to this world on winter solstice 12-21-12. Pretty neat, huh? It's a big hit on YouTube. I did the animation myself.
answer: If they all knew, don't you think somebody would tell us?

question: They can't. Just think about it. First the stockmarket would crash... Then the economy... boom. The dollar... boom. And then the people in the streets... Boom, boom! Pandemonium, revolution, war! They would never tell us. Beer? Only if you're some Sheik, Bill Gates, or maybe one of those Russian billionaires do you stand a chance to buy a seat.
answer: A seat? Oh... I see.

question: No really... One of my listeners, a geography professor at UTSC, has even figured out where they're building them. He sent me a map.
answer: Well... Charlie, I think I gotta go. My kids are sleeping.

question: Get them out of Yellowstone, man. It's gonna get ugly here.
answer: Night, Charlie.

question: Why don't we make a baby?
answer: Stop it! We're in public.

question: Honey, I created them. And now suddenly I can't touch them? You always act strange after he shows up?
answer: Just because I don't care for your arrogant humor doesn't mean I'm acting strange. He is the father of my kids.

question: Maybe biologically. Can I remind you what that guy did? First you gave up med school to have Noah... Then you practically raise him and Lilly by yourself while he sat glued to a laptop writing that junk.
answer: Some of his stuff is actually... He's published Gordon. Did you see that?

question: Sir, you have to initiate the boarding process immediately.
answer: Is this even possible? What's our information from China?

question: They estimate four of the ships will be ready for launch.
answer: Only four?

question: If it's alright with you sir, I'll brief the panel about the new development.
answer: I'd rather have Adrian do that. They trust him. I told him to be in on the meeting. Ladies and Gentlemen, we all knew this day would come. But we never imagined it would come this soon. I would like to pass this over to my science advisor, Adrian Helmsley.

question: I'll be right there. Thank you ladies and gentlemen. Let's hear it for the one and only Tony Delgado... And I'm Harry Helmsley and we'll be back after a short pit stop.
answer: Dad... what I have to tell you is very serious... You remember when I told you about the dam in China? Well, it's happening much sooner than we anticipated. The President has ordered us to clear out the White House.

question: Hah... About time someone cleaned up that mess.
answer: Where are you, dad? What exactly is the course of the `Freedom' right now?...

question: It's all good, Adrian. Don't worry about your old man. You have more important things to do now. You know, your mom and I, we had a hell of a great life... and a hell of a great kid too. ... Besides, I could never leave Tony alone. You know how he can't keep decent time by himself.
answer: I love you, dad.

question: Love you too, son. Hey Herb. Get me a double Jack on the rocks.
answer: After twenty-five years on the wagon?

question: Why not? Who cares how long we do certain things? How long we drink booze, how long we talk to people... Or how long we don't talk to people.
answer: Woah!... Harry, what's the matter with you? Let's go. We're back on.

question: Call your kid, you stubborn old ass. Promise me, Tony... please.
answer: Yeah, maybe I should call him...

question: You wait here for me! You watch the ship while Captain Curtis talks to the pirate. Okay?
answer: ... I wish you guys at home could see this on TV... How did you make it up here? Thought you were toast.

question: The spaceships Charlie, where are they?
answer: You can't make it there.

question: We have a plane. We can get you out of here too. Let's go Charlie!
answer: You'll never make it out in time. Just stay and enjoy the big bang. That your kid?

question: Where is that god damn map!
answer: Easy, easy. Watch the mic... I don't know. Somewhere in my camper. Wow! Look at that!... Fly birdies fly! This marks the last day of the United States of America folks and by tomorrow... ... the last of mankind. Soon they'll see us from a million miles away, out there in the milky way...

question: Just a few minutes ago Yellowstone erupted, sir. The ash cloud will reach Washington in roughly 7 hours. Maybe 6. We have strong easterly winds...
answer: And the crustal displacement?

question: No one knows, sir.
answer: Let's get the government airborne and... I mean now. Where is the President, Sally? The whole North American continent is about to perish, and Wilson decides to go to church!

question: He's praying sir. Which considering the circumstances is not a bad idea.
answer: Maybe. But right now I need the leader of the free world off his knees and on Air Force One. Wheels up 1900 hours. Can I leave that with you Helmsley?

question: Mr. President? We need to get you out of Washington immediately.
answer: Now matter how idealistic you are taking office. You lose your innocence behind that desk.

question: That's not your fault sir.
answer: You sound like Anheuser. Laura's never looked at me like that before. Only once... When I told her, her mother had died. You knew the first lady?

question: A little.
answer: You know what she said to me that night we brought her to the hospital?

question: There would have been chaos, sir.
answer: You know what I believe, Adrian. I believe nature should choose for itself, from itself. Don't let her go. You'll regret it if you do. Prove to Laura what kind of a man you are. And I'll do the same... You go now. And watch your back for Anheuser.

question: But sir?
answer: Go. That's an order Helmsley. Would you tell my daughter... there's nothing on earth that I cherish more than her.

question: The President is not coming. I couldn't convince him to.
answer: So, the captain doesn't want to leave his sinking ship?

question: What about the Speaker of the House?
answer: In this chaos... I have no idea!

question: But she's Commander In Chief now. Sir, I just think -
answer: I don't care what you think, Helmsley. Your ass only made it into the White House, because your old man knew the First Lady... and because of all that affirmative action bullshit. There was a white kid, much more qualified than you. Just so you know.

question: You check the main bus for the hydraulics. I'll balance the tanks.
answer: Uh... What?

question: Work the radio and keep an eye on the fuel, okay?
answer: We have to get going! We're not gonna make it!

question: Shut up! We will! GOVNO! . Help me pull!
answer: Was that the Eiffel Tower?

question: But Lin is my brother. He is working inside the big tunnels, where the ships are made. What is in your wisdom for us to do, great Lama... if Lin is right, if our world is indeed coming to an end? It's full, great Lama. It can hold no more!
answer: Bata! Neng is coming!

question: Mother, I got a message from Lin. He wants us to meet him in Cho Ming, at the west gate. He says he can get us on one of the ships he is working on.
answer: I thought Lin is working on the dam?

question: The dam is a ship, Mother. The government lied to us. There will be a big flood.
answer: Not here in the mountains... Let's eat first.

question: Be careful, Noh'!
answer: How did you meet Dr. Silberman? He's great, isn't he?

question: I think for the same reasons you did. You know, after breast feeding two kids... Did your husband ask you to get your's done?
answer: We are not married. And we probably never will... But he paid for them.

question: They seem to like each other.
answer: I guess... So tell me Mr. Karpov - how much did you pay?

question: One billion euro, per seat.
answer: That's disgusting.

question: Hi guys. The plan is to refuel in Hawaii. So, buckle up... Gordon and I will do the rest.
answer: Let's get this straight, Sasha. I'm not a pilot. I'm a plastic surgeon. I just took some lessons to overcome my fear of flying.

question: Why did you give up?
answer: It didn't work. What about the wheels we lost at take- off?

question: There's 14 on each side. Some of them must still be there. Still nothing from the tower?
answer: Guys, you really oughta take a look at this.

question: Can I come in?
answer: I've got nothing to say to you.

question: But I do... Your Dad and I... we were trying to protect you. But you were doing a good job.
answer: Sure, if your name's Da Vinci or Picasso. But if you're some young talent in Podunk, Texas, sorry you're not famous enough. People like you and Anheuser and my father - you think you can play God.

question: You know what your father believed. That nature will choose itself from itself.
answer: That's bullshit and you know it. It's the fittest, the richest and the strongest that survive.

question: That's not true. What would you say were the chances of a first time, middle-aged writer, who barely sold 500 copies of his novel making it on board this plane?
answer: Zero. What's your point?

question: It's called `Farewell Atlantis' and it's a fantastic read. It's part of our legacy now. What if I tried to sort some of this mess out? I need to know you can forgive me...
answer: I need to know that too, Adrian.

question: Couldn't sleep huh? Me neither.
answer: Anything?

question: Nothing, just static. Not even an emergency signal.
answer: I can't think about what's going on down there. I wanted to thank you. For coming back for us.

question: I couldn't have left you...
answer: Do you think people change?

question: By `people' are we talking about me?
answer: Do you think you've changed since we separated?

question: Well I certainly eat a lot more cereal now...
answer: You know, you always had tunnel vision. You could always just block things out and write. You blocked all of us out Jackson.

question: Do you love him? Gordon...
answer: I love him enough.

question: Let's go wake up the kids.
answer: Why do you hate Gordon?

question: What are you talking about? I don't hate Gordon.
answer: But you don't like him either.

question: I don't know him that well.
answer: But I know him. He's really nice. You should talk to him more often. You guys would get along really well.

question: I should have listened to you, Dr. Silberman. I actually liked the way I looked before that monster talked me into it.
answer: Did you know he asked for a discount... and he paid in installments?

question: Cheap bastard.
answer: You're better off without him. What he said about you and Sasha, is it true?

question: Satnam?
answer: On the Nampan Plateau...

question: What?!
answer: There's a tidal wave coming from the East! It's huge!

question: Satnam, what happened?
answer: We never got picked up, Adrian, the airlift never came! I have to go!

question: What does this mean?
answer: The flooding will happen earlier. Bobby, can you plug in the new data please? Satnam didn't get picked up. This one is at least 1500 meters high!

question: Talk to me Helmsley. What does this mean for us?
answer: Bobby, plug in the new data and adjust the count down?

question: Anheuser convinced them all to launch. Anheuser! We have to stop this madness. Bobby, make sure the other bridges can hear this.
answer: What do you think you're doing?

question: I know exactly what I'm doing. Turn it on! This is Adrian Helmsley, science advisor to President Wilson... I know we've all been involved in making difficult decisions... to save our human civilization... ... But to be human means to care for each other, and civilization means to work together to create a better life. If that's true there is nothing human and nothing civilized about what we're doing here. Ask yourselves ... Can we really stand by and let all those people out there die? A civilization that allows that, does not deserve to survive.
answer: We'll miss you Helmsley but somehow we'll get by. Officer switch that off. That's an order soldier.

question: Don't do it! We have to open our gates and let these people in. All of them.
answer: Have you lost your mind? Look at the countdown. We have less than five minutes left... And none of our ships have the resources to feed those people. If you save them today we all starve tomorrow. Do you wanna be responsible for the extinction of the human race? Can you handle that, Adrian?!
